titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michael Grumley Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 18, 2019 at 03:06

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Michael Grumley Papers primarily contain his writings and supporting research material, with a small amount of personal correspondence and personal papers. More than half of the collection consists of his creative writings and drawings, spanning his college years through his career as a freelance author, many of which were not published during his lifetime. The collection holds files on Grumley's published work, including his one novel and his four books on the topics of Atlantis, Sasquatch, sadomasochism, and night workers, in addition to his columns and criticism for periodicals such as the New York Native and the Philadelphia Gay News. The papers also include his daily journals and engagement calendars.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the Michael Grumley Estate on the Sinclair Lewis Fund, 1998.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Michael Grumley Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Michael Grumley Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: After Robert Ferro's death, all papers remaining in the rental apartment he shared with Michael Grumley were removed by Ferro's siblings; the papers were then sorted into groups of files for each author, and packed for transfer to Yale. Material related to their coauthored volume Atlantis had been sorted into Ferro's cartons, but considering the book's non-fiction nature and publisher, it was moved into Grumley's papers during processing.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Robert Ferro Papers (YCAL MSS 322) holds additional personal and business correspondence addressed to both Grumley and Ferro as well as material related to Grumley's memorial service, which was arranged by Ferro; also filed there are drafts of a few unpublished works coauthored by the couple.

bioghist.head: Michael Grumley (1941-1988)
bioghist.p: The illustrator and writer Michael Grumley was born in Davenport, Iowa, on July 6, 1941, and raised in nearby Bettendorf, Iowa, with his three brothers Charles, Terry, and Timothy. He attended the University of Denver and Mexico City College before earning a BA degree from the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 1964, after which he took a seasonal position with the Johnson's Wax Pavilion at the New York World's Fair. He returned to work at the fair the next summer, and when it closed in October 1965, Grumley applied to City College of the City University of New York for graduate study in literature. He enrolled at CUNY in January in 1966, but transferred in February 1967 to the Writers' Workshop at the University of Iowa, where he studied writing with Kurt Vonnegut and took film courses. While at Iowa Grumley met fellow Workshop student Robert Ferro (1941-1988; MFA 1967), and by semester's end, the two had begun their life together. Known to their friends as "the Ferro-Grumleys," the couple lived primarily on New York's Upper West Side for twenty years, but also spent periods of time in Rome and London. Another favorite place was the Ferro family's oceanfront home in Sea Girt, New Jersey, where they regularly entertained friends and family.

During the early 1980s Grumley worked part-time at Endicott Booksellers, a neighborhood store, otherwise devoting much of his energy to his research and writing projects. Four of his five published books dealt with disparate topics, but all explored alternative theories and lifestyles. The first, Atlantis: the Autobiography of a Search (Doubleday, 1970), was co-written with Robert Ferro, and presented a dual first-person narrative of their trip to the Bahamas in the Ferro family's yacht. His second, also for Doubleday, was There Are Giants in the Earth (1974), a study of legends surrounding Bigfoot (Sasquatch). Grumley provided the text to accompany Ed Gallucci's photographs for Hard Corps: Studies in Leather and Sadomasochism (Dutton, 1977). His After Midnight (Scribner, 1978) profiled a group of people employed on night shifts, including workers in a zoo, hospital, baby powder factory, and on a shrimp boat. Grumley wrote reviews and essays for periodicals such as Stagebill , Philadelphia Gay News , and New York Native , where his weekly column, "Uptown," was regularly featured between 1980 and 1984. Additionally, he contributed illustrations to a number of publications such as Black Men/White Men: a Gay Anthology (Gay Sunshine Press, 1983). His final work, Life Drawing: a novel (Grove Weidenfeld, 1991) was published posthumously.

Michael Grumley and Robert Ferro were affiliated with a literary group known as the Violet Quill, whose seven members, as men writing for men, are regarded as one of the strongest collective voices of the gay male experience in the post-Stonewall era. Authors Christopher Cox, Andrew Holleran, Felice Picano, Edmund White, George Whitmore, Ferro, and Grumley met several times in 1979, 1980, and 1981 to read aloud from their works in progress. Also on the agenda were discussions of how they could work together to promote recognition, acceptance, and publication of gay literature beyond the boundaries of their own community. Of the VQ writers, Michael Grumley and Robert Ferro were the first to die from AIDS-related complications, both in 1988 at age 46, Grumley on April 28 and Ferro on July 11; they were followed by Whitmore in 1989 and Cox in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Michael Grumley Papers primarily contain his writings and supporting research material, with a small amount of personal correspondence and personal papers. More than half of the collection consists of his creative writings and drawings, spanning his college years through his career as a freelance author, many of which were not published during his lifetime. In addition to his one novel and his four books on the topics of Atlantis, Sasquatch, sadomasochism, and night workers, Grumley wrote columns and criticism for periodicals such as the New York Native and the Philadelphia Gay News . His files hold research notes, contracts, drafts, tear sheets, reviews, and fan mail.

While most of Grumley's writings explored alternative legends and lifestyles, he also composed short works of whimsy for both children and adults. In addition to preparing texts, he drew illustrations for several of his own projects, such as a proposed book on tarot, and created images to accompany other writers' words; also in the collection are more than one hundred of his stylized ink drawings. Equally important are Grumley's set of daily journals and engagement calendars which provide an intimate narrative of the activities, culture, and community of an American writer fully experiencing life in New York, Rome, and London in the 1970s and 1980s, in particular a life lived in the midst of the AIDS epidemic.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence and Personal Papers (1910-1988); II. Writings (1963-1987); and III. Other Papers (1971-1988).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Correspondence; Personal Papers; and Calendars and Journals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains some correspondence files and a few personal papers, including a set of calendars and daily journals kept by Grumley. Little was retained in the way of personal correspondence; the collection holds just a few letters from members of his family, notably those from his brother Terry who was serving with the Peace Corps in Nicaragua. There are a few letters from the playwright Robert Gordon and a single card from Robert Ferro. Personal Papers includes a folder of horoscope, tarot card, and numerology readings for both Grumley and Ferro, as well as some school, tax, and unemployment records. Notable in the subseries are Grumley's files on the 1964 New York World's Fair (including a typed "diary" made during the fair's final days), and an Italian court invoice for the couple's April 1971 arrest, week-long imprisonment, and trial on a public indecency charge; those traumatic events are fully described in Grumley's daily journal in the following subseries. Also here are papers that record the two public exhibitions of Grumley's drawings, and a resume and arts guide that document his brief turn as a model.

Perhaps the most important of the personal papers are the twenty-year sets of engagement calendars and daily journals. As they record the activities of the household, Robert Ferro also made notations in the calendars, but they appear to have been kept primarily by Grumley. The journals, which are exclusively in Grumley's hand, in particular provide a compelling narrative of the lives of "the Ferro-Grumleys" and their friends, describing the activities, events, relationships, meals, travels, and, in the 1980s, the incessant presence if symptoms, treatments, hospitalizations, and memorial services, as AIDS began to decimate their community, as well as his own health. Grumley also mentions the meetings of the Violet Quill writers group in March, April, and July 1980, and March 1981, and the literary works featured.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes snapshot photographs of Grumley and Ferro

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains a set of engagement and wall calendars, followed by a set of daily journals; both are chronologically arranged. There are two calendars each for the years 1976 and 1977, and there is no calendar for 1983.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Articles and Reviews; Books; and Other Writings and Drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence and research files supporting Grumley's writing projects, as well as contracts, notes, drafts, reviews, and fan mail pertaining to his published works.

The first subseries, Articles and Reviews, holds examples of his work for hire, in particular his regular column, "Uptown," published in the New York Native between 1980 and 1984. The collection holds clippings and tear sheets from the paper, as well as a second set of tear sheets onto which Grumley had collaged other texts and images, and enclosed inside personally decorated covers. The Books subseries holds material on Grumley's published work; it includes some correspondence, but mainly holds research notes, drafts, and various proofs and mechanicals. After Midnight (working title "Night People") contains drafts of the full manuscript as well as files on each of the individual chapters, which contain his research material, clippings, photographs, and some correspondence on the personalities profiled. One chapter, "AKA Gloria," a profile of actress Gloria Rossi, was submitted with a National Endowment for the Arts grant application and to New York magazine. Atlantis: the Autobiography of a Search was a collaborative effort between Grumley and Ferro, with each writing alternate chapters. The project files also hold photographs taken by Grumley during their excursion, as well as underwater photographs made by the noted explorer Pino Turolla (1921-1984).

Other Writings and Drawings is the largest subseries, and spans Grumley's college essays through to the book-length projects he worked on through the 1980s, most of which went unpublished during his lifetime. Some of his early essays were published in Cheshire , the University of Wisconsin's literary journal. A folder of short pieces he labeled "Vonnegut" were apparently submitted to his instructor at Iowa, though they have no annotations or remarks by him. A few of Grumley's writings are autobiographical in nature, such as the essay "I Was a Cast of Thousands," which describes his experiences as an extra in a half-dozen films including The Eyes of Laura Mars (1978) and Ragtime (1981). When Grumley created illustrations for his writings, their presence is noted in the folder listing. A group of folders at the end of the series hold Miscellaneous Drawings and Collages, which are sets of Grumley's stylized line drawings, some of which have collage elements added, as well as individual drawings that appear unrelated to texts or each other; most are not dated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Subject Files, and Writings of Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains files of clippings kept by Grumley, which cover topics of personal and professional interest. Some relate to his published writings and supplement those filed in Series II. Writings by Others contains a photocopy of a work by fellow VQ author Andrew Holleran, and a set of files for a project Grumley was working on, as a ghostwriter, with his personal physician; it is unclear how much of the writing was done by Grumley.
